title: Cat. 87  Fragment of a Cup, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Cup  
Late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 4.2 × 2.5 × 0.7 cm (1 5/8 × 1 × 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1228

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent bubbly aquamarine, translucent gray-blue, and opaque white and brick-red glass. Cup fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished. The fragment preserves a small segment of the outsplayed rim and double carinated profile. The mosaic pattern is formed from sections of a single cane in a gray-blue ground with a central red dot and a concentric white ring surrounded by a ring of ten white dots. There appears to be a matrix of bubbly aquamarine glass between these canes that reads as occasional streaks. The gray-blue cane ground is the predominant color.

Small segment of rim preserved, all other edges are broken. The back and edges retain a light-brown weathering crust and incrustation; the interior has been repolished and pits in the surface still retain this same weathering product.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 87 Fragment of a Cup, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.

</section>
